The Literary iPhone


If you’re like me, you’ve become addicted to your iPhone in the oddest ways, even though the phone service itself is horrible. I use it as a flashlight when I walk my son to the bathroom at night, and everyone knows it’s a great distraction for your kids (Bebot, Brushes). That is if you can get it away from them or if they don’t make odd phone calls or emails to your clients (if you’ve ever gotten an email from me with nothing but “yrixoxyt” in the body, it came from Seamus).

Among the myriad practical little apps, I became obsessed with “The Weather Channel” app over the summer, hoping each time that the little cloud icons would turn to sun (they never did). But what I truly love about my iPhone is the Shorter Oxford English Dictionary app. For me, that alone is worth the price. Yes, it’s expensive for an iPhone app, but we’re talking about a massive dictionary, second only to the OED itself, always at your side (My other preferred dictionary, the controversial Merriam-Webster Unabridged, I use online, if needed). The truly geeky can even use the “random word” button – when faced with nothing else to do – until you find something you don’t know.

More than once I’ve used IndieBound’s iPhone app for looking up books when the conversation hinges upon remembering that author (and anyone who knows me knows I have a horrible memory). “The something Hedgehog, wasn’t it…?” yes, he says confidently, “Elegance of the Hedgehog” with the iPhone under the table.

Of course, the reader wars are upon us, with Stanza, Amazon and Barnes & Noble’s e-readers, among others, competing – on what, I don’t know. I did manage to read Robert Louis Stevenson’s Treasure Island on my iPhone via Stanza when my five-year-old lost interest in the hardcopy we were reading. But I’ve yet to be convinced that it’s worth paying for any books there besides maybe something to read in an emergency – you do know about reading emergencies, don’t you?

What’s more, despite the promise of e-readers, the so-called “long-tail” doesn’t yet exist. When the entire backlist of New Directions, Dalkey Archive and so on are available in the Kindle store, then maybe.

Feel like brushing up on the play while waiting in line for your Shakespeare in the Park tickets? Read it on the free playshakespeare app, a companion to the PlayShakespeare.com Website. You’re limited to only one version (First Folio of 1623 and the Globe Edition of 1866), but it’s quite a comprehensive app and will leave you sifting through sonnets for hours on end.

On the margins of usefulness, there’s Next Read that allows you to keep lists of books and who recommended them.

So many apps, many more I’m sure I don’t know about, but I think one of the most interesting apps for the iPhone is one surely to help you out in a reading emergency: Electric Literature is a lit-mag with versions in paper, Kindle, e-readers and the iPhone (although, unfortunately, the iPhone version is only for one issue, not a subscription). Short stories by authors you may or may or may not know at your finger tips. When carrying around the latest issue of Brick isn’t an option, you’ll find plenty to keep you busy with “Electric Literature.” The app doesn’t have all the bells and whistles of other e-readers, but it does have the one thing that’s paramount no matter what form…the text.

Carolyn, at the LATimes Jacket Copy blog, runs with the idea and adds some more depth to the “Literary iPhone.”
